005package edu.wpi.first.wpilibj;
006
007import static edu.wpi.first.units.Units.Meters;
008import static edu.wpi.first.units.Units.Microsecond;
009import static edu.wpi.first.units.Units.Microseconds;
010import static edu.wpi.first.units.Units.Value;
011
012import edu.wpi.first.math.MathUtil;
013import edu.wpi.first.units.collections.LongToObjectHashMap;
014import edu.wpi.first.units.measure.Dimensionless;
015import edu.wpi.first.units.measure.Distance;
016import edu.wpi.first.units.measure.Frequency;
017import edu.wpi.first.units.measure.LinearVelocity;
018import edu.wpi.first.units.measure.Time;
019import edu.wpi.first.util.WPIUtilJNI;
020import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.util.Color;
021import java.util.Map;
022import java.util.Objects;
023import java.util.function.BooleanSupplier;
024import java.util.function.DoubleSupplier;
025
026/**
027 * An LED pattern controls lights on an LED strip to command patterns of color that may change over
028 * time. Dynamic patterns should synchronize on an external clock for timed-based animations ({@link
029 * WPIUtilJNI#now()} is recommended, since it can be mocked in simulation and unit tests), or on
030 * some other dynamic input (see {@link #synchronizedBlink(BooleanSupplier)}, for example).
031 *
032 * <p>Patterns should be updated periodically in order for animations to play smoothly. For example,
033 * a hypothetical LED subsystem could create a {@code Command} that will continuously apply the
034 * pattern to its LED data buffer as part of the main periodic loop.
035 *
036 * <pre><code>
037 *   public class LEDs extends SubsystemBase {
038 *     private final AddressableLED m_led = new AddressableLED(0);
039 *     private final AddressableLEDBuffer m_ledData = new AddressableLEDBuffer(120);
040 *
041 *     public LEDs() {
042 *       m_led.setLength(120);
043 *       m_led.start();
044 *     }
045 *
046 *    {@literal @}Override
047 *     public void periodic() {
048 *       m_led.writeData(m_ledData);
049 *     }
050 *
051 *     public Command runPattern(LEDPattern pattern) {
052 *       return run(() -> pattern.applyTo(m_ledData));
053 *     }
054 *   }
055 * </code></pre>
056 *
057 * <p>LED patterns are stateless, and as such can be applied to multiple LED strips (or different
058 * sections of the same LED strip, since the roboRIO can only drive a single LED strip). In this
059 * example, we split the single buffer into two views - one for the section of the LED strip on the
060 * left side of a robot, and another view for the section of LEDs on the right side. The same
061 * pattern is able to be applied to both sides.
062 *
063 * <pre><code>
064 *   public class LEDs extends SubsystemBase {
065 *     private final AddressableLED m_led = new AddressableLED(0);
066 *     private final AddressableLEDBuffer m_ledData = new AddressableLEDBuffer(60);
067 *     private final AddressableLEDBufferView m_leftData = m_ledData.createView(0, 29);
068 *     private final AddressableLEDBufferView m_rightData = m_ledData.createView(30, 59).reversed();
069 *
070 *     public LEDs() {
071 *       m_led.setLength(60);
072 *       m_led.start();
073 *     }
074 *
075 *    {@literal @}Override
076 *     public void periodic() {
077 *       m_led.writeData(m_ledData);
078 *     }
079 *
080 *     public Command runPattern(LEDPattern pattern) {
081 *       // Use the single input pattern to drive both sides
082 *       return runSplitPatterns(pattern, pattern);
083 *     }
084 *
085 *     public Command runSplitPatterns(LEDPattern left, LEDPattern right) {
086 *       return run(() -> {
087 *         left.applyTo(m_leftData);
088 *         right.applyTo(m_rightData);
089 *       });
090 *     }
091 *   }
092 * </code></pre>
093 */
094@FunctionalInterface
095public interface LEDPattern {
096  /**
097   * Writes the pattern to an LED buffer. Dynamic animations should be called periodically (such as
098   * with a command or with a periodic method) to refresh the buffer over time.
099   *
100   * <p>This method is intentionally designed to use separate objects for reading and writing data.
101   * By splitting them up, we can easily modify the behavior of some base pattern to make it {@link
102   * #scrollAtRelativeSpeed(Frequency) scroll}, {@link #blink(Time, Time) blink}, or {@link
103   * #breathe(Time) breathe} by intercepting the data writes to transform their behavior to whatever
104   * we like.
105   *
106   * @param reader data reader for accessing buffer length and current colors
107   * @param writer data writer for setting new LED colors on the buffer
108   */
109  void applyTo(LEDReader reader, LEDWriter writer);
110
111  /**
112   * Convenience for {@link #applyTo(LEDReader, LEDWriter)} when one object provides both a read and
113   * a write interface. This is most helpful for playing an animated pattern directly on an {@link
114   * AddressableLEDBuffer} for the sake of code clarity.
115   *
116   * <pre><code>
117   *   AddressableLEDBuffer data = new AddressableLEDBuffer(120);
118   *   LEDPattern pattern = ...
119   *
120   *   void periodic() {
121   *     pattern.applyTo(data);
122   *   }
123   * </code></pre>
124   *
125   * @param readWriter the object to use for both reading and writing to a set of LEDs
126   * @param <T> the type of the object that can both read and write LED data
127   */
128  default <T extends LEDReader & LEDWriter> void applyTo(T readWriter) {
129    applyTo(readWriter, readWriter);
130  }
131
132  /**
133   * Creates a pattern that displays this one in reverse. Scrolling patterns will scroll in the
134   * opposite direction (but at the same speed). It will treat the end of an LED strip as the start,
135   * and the start of the strip as the end. This can be useful for making ping-pong patterns that
136   * travel from one end of an LED strip to the other, then reverse direction and move back to the
137   * start. This can also be useful when working with LED strips connected in a serpentine pattern
138   * (where the start of one strip is connected to the end of the previous one); however, consider
139   * using a {@link AddressableLEDBufferView#reversed() reversed view} of the overall buffer for
140   * that segment rather than reversing patterns.
141   *
142   * @return the reverse pattern
143   * @see AddressableLEDBufferView#reversed()
144   */
145  default LEDPattern reversed() {
146    return (reader, writer) -> {
147      int bufLen = reader.getLength();
148      applyTo(reader, (i, r, g, b) -> writer.setRGB((bufLen - 1) - i, r, g, b));
149    };
150  }
151
152  /**
153   * Creates a pattern that plays this one, but offset by a certain number of LEDs. The offset
154   * pattern will wrap around, if necessary.
155   *
156   * @param offset how many LEDs to offset by
157   * @return the offset pattern
158   */
159  default LEDPattern offsetBy(int offset) {
160    return (reader, writer) -> {
161      int bufLen = reader.getLength();
162      applyTo(
163          reader,
164          (i, r, g, b) -> {
165            int shiftedIndex = Math.floorMod(i + offset, bufLen);
166            writer.setRGB(shiftedIndex, r, g, b);
167          });
168    };
169  }
170
171  /**
172   * Creates a pattern that plays this one scrolling up the buffer. The velocity controls how fast
173   * the pattern returns back to its original position, and is in terms of the length of the LED
174   * strip; scrolling across a segment that is 10 LEDs long will travel twice as fast as on a
175   * segment that's only 5 LEDs long (assuming equal LED density on both segments).
176   *
177   * <p>For example, scrolling a pattern by one quarter of any LED strip's length per second,
178   * regardless of the total number of LEDs on that strip:
179   *
180   * <pre>
181   *   LEDPattern rainbow = LEDPattern.rainbow(255, 255);
182   *   LEDPattern scrollingRainbow = rainbow.scrollAtRelativeSpeed(Percent.per(Second).of(25));
183   * </pre>
184   *
185   * @param velocity how fast the pattern should move, in terms of how long it takes to do a full
186   *     scroll along the length of LEDs and return back to the starting position
187   * @return the scrolling pattern
188   */
189  default LEDPattern scrollAtRelativeSpeed(Frequency velocity) {
190    final double periodMicros = velocity.asPeriod().in(Microseconds);
191
192    return (reader, writer) -> {
193      int bufLen = reader.getLength();
194      long now = WPIUtilJNI.now();
195
196      // index should move by (buf.length) / (period)
197      double t = (now % (long) periodMicros) / periodMicros;
198      int offset = (int) (t * bufLen);
199
200      applyTo(
201          reader,
202          (i, r, g, b) -> {
203            // floorMod so if the offset is negative, we still get positive outputs
204            int shiftedIndex = Math.floorMod(i + offset, bufLen);
205
206            writer.setRGB(shiftedIndex, r, g, b);
207          });
208    };
209  }
210
211  /**
212   * Creates a pattern that plays this one scrolling up an LED strip. A negative velocity makes the
213   * pattern play in reverse.
214   *
215   * <p>For example, scrolling a pattern at 4 inches per second along an LED strip with 60 LEDs per
216   * meter:
217   *
218   * <pre>
219   *   // LEDs per meter, a known value taken from the spec sheet of our particular LED strip
220   *   Distance LED_SPACING = Meters.of(1.0 / 60);
221   *
222   *   LEDPattern rainbow = LEDPattern.rainbow();
223   *   LEDPattern scrollingRainbow =
224   *     rainbow.scrollAtAbsoluteSpeed(InchesPerSecond.of(4), LED_SPACING);
225   * </pre>
226   *
227   * <p>Note that this pattern will scroll <i>faster</i> if applied to a less dense LED strip (such
228   * as 30 LEDs per meter), or <i>slower</i> if applied to a denser LED strip (such as 120 or 144
229   * LEDs per meter).
230   *
231   * @param velocity how fast the pattern should move along a physical LED strip
232   * @param ledSpacing the distance between adjacent LEDs on the physical LED strip
233   * @return the scrolling pattern
234   */
235  default LEDPattern scrollAtAbsoluteSpeed(LinearVelocity velocity, Distance ledSpacing) {
236    // eg velocity = 10 m/s, spacing = 0.01m
237    // meters per micro = 1e-5 m/us
238    // micros per LED = 1e-2 m / (1e-5 m/us) = 1e-3 us
239
240    var metersPerMicro = velocity.in(Meters.per(Microsecond));
241    var microsPerLED = (int) (ledSpacing.in(Meters) / metersPerMicro);
242
243    return (reader, writer) -> {
244      int bufLen = reader.getLength();
245      long now = WPIUtilJNI.now();
246
247      // every step in time that's a multiple of microsPerLED will increment the offset by 1
248      var offset = now / microsPerLED;
249
250      applyTo(
251          reader,
252          (i, r, g, b) -> {
253            // floorMod so if the offset is negative, we still get positive outputs
254            int shiftedIndex = Math.floorMod(i + offset, bufLen);
255
256            writer.setRGB(shiftedIndex, r, g, b);
257          });
258    };
259  }
260
261  /**
262   * Creates a pattern that switches between playing this pattern and turning the entire LED strip
263   * off.
264   *
265   * @param onTime how long the pattern should play for, per cycle
266   * @param offTime how long the pattern should be turned off for, per cycle
267   * @return the blinking pattern
268   */
269  default LEDPattern blink(Time onTime, Time offTime) {
270    final long totalTimeMicros = (long) (onTime.in(Microseconds) + offTime.in(Microseconds));
271    final long onTimeMicros = (long) onTime.in(Microseconds);
272
273    return (reader, writer) -> {
274      if (WPIUtilJNI.now() % totalTimeMicros < onTimeMicros) {
275        applyTo(reader, writer);
276      } else {
277        kOff.applyTo(reader, writer);
278      }
279    };
280  }
281
282  /**
283   * Like {@link #blink(Time, Time) blink(onTime, offTime)}, but where the "off" time is exactly
284   * equal to the "on" time.
285   *
286   * @param onTime how long the pattern should play for (and be turned off for), per cycle
287   * @return the blinking pattern
288   */
289  default LEDPattern blink(Time onTime) {
290    return blink(onTime, onTime);
291  }
292
293  /**
294   * Creates a pattern that blinks this one on and off in sync with a true/false signal. The pattern
295   * will play while the signal outputs {@code true}, and will turn off while the signal outputs
296   * {@code false}.
297   *
298   * @param signal the signal to synchronize with
299   * @return the blinking pattern
300   */
301  default LEDPattern synchronizedBlink(BooleanSupplier signal) {
302    return (reader, writer) -> {
303      if (signal.getAsBoolean()) {
304        applyTo(reader, writer);
305      } else {
306        kOff.applyTo(reader, writer);
307      }
308    };
309  }
310
311  /**
312   * Creates a pattern that brightens and dims this one over time. Brightness follows a sinusoidal
313   * pattern.
314   *
315   * @param period how fast the breathing pattern should complete a single cycle
316   * @return the breathing pattern
317   */
318  default LEDPattern breathe(Time period) {
319    final long periodMicros = (long) period.in(Microseconds);
320
321    return (reader, writer) -> {
322      applyTo(
323          reader,
324          (i, r, g, b) -> {
325            // How far we are in the cycle, in the range [0, 1)
326            double t = (WPIUtilJNI.now() % periodMicros) / (double) periodMicros;
327            double phase = t * 2 * Math.PI;
328
329            // Apply the cosine function and shift its output from [-1, 1] to [0, 1]
330            // Use cosine so the period starts at 100% brightness
331            double dim = (Math.cos(phase) + 1) / 2.0;
332
333            int output = Color.lerpRGB(0, 0, 0, r, g, b, dim);
334
335            writer.setRGB(
336                i,
337                Color.unpackRGB(output, Color.RGBChannel.kRed),
338                Color.unpackRGB(output, Color.RGBChannel.kGreen),
339                Color.unpackRGB(output, Color.RGBChannel.kBlue));
340          });
341    };
342  }
343
344  /**
345   * Creates a pattern that plays this pattern overlaid on another. Anywhere this pattern sets an
346   * LED to off (or {@link Color#kBlack}), the base pattern will be displayed instead.
347   *
348   * @param base the base pattern to overlay on top of
349   * @return the combined overlay pattern
350   */
351  default LEDPattern overlayOn(LEDPattern base) {
352    return (reader, writer) -> {
353      // write the base pattern down first...
354      base.applyTo(reader, writer);
355
356      // ... then, overwrite with the illuminated LEDs from the overlay
357      applyTo(
358          reader,
359          (i, r, g, b) -> {
360            if (r != 0 || g != 0 || b != 0) {
361              writer.setRGB(i, r, g, b);
362            }
363          });
364    };
365  }
366
367  /**
368   * Creates a pattern that displays outputs as a combination of this pattern and another. Color
369   * values are calculated as the average color of both patterns; if both patterns set the same LED
370   * to the same color, then it is set to that color, but if one pattern sets to one color and the
371   * other pattern sets it to off, then it will show the color of the first pattern but at
372   * approximately half brightness. This is different from {@link #overlayOn}, which will show the
373   * base pattern at full brightness if the overlay is set to off at that position.
374   *
375   * @param other the pattern to blend with
376   * @return the blended pattern
377   */
378  default LEDPattern blend(LEDPattern other) {
379    return (reader, writer) -> {
380      applyTo(reader, writer);
381
382      other.applyTo(
383          reader,
384          (i, r, g, b) -> {
385            int blendedRGB =
386                Color.lerpRGB(
387                    reader.getRed(i), reader.getGreen(i), reader.getBlue(i), r, g, b, 0.5);
388
389            writer.setRGB(
390                i,
391                Color.unpackRGB(blendedRGB, Color.RGBChannel.kRed),
392                Color.unpackRGB(blendedRGB, Color.RGBChannel.kGreen),
393                Color.unpackRGB(blendedRGB, Color.RGBChannel.kBlue));
394          });
395    };
396  }
397
398  /**
399   * Similar to {@link #blend(LEDPattern)}, but performs a bitwise mask on each color channel rather
400   * than averaging the colors for each LED. This can be helpful for displaying only a portion of
401   * the base pattern by applying a mask that sets the desired area to white, and all other areas to
402   * black. However, it can also be used to display only certain color channels or hues; for
403   * example, masking with {@code LEDPattern.color(Color.kRed)} will turn off the green and blue
404   * channels on the output pattern, leaving only the red LEDs to be illuminated.
405   *
406   * @param mask the mask to apply
407   * @return the masked pattern
408   */
409  default LEDPattern mask(LEDPattern mask) {
410    return (reader, writer) -> {
411      // Apply the current pattern down as normal...
412      applyTo(reader, writer);
413
414      mask.applyTo(
415          reader,
416          (i, r, g, b) -> {
417            // ... then perform a bitwise AND operation on each channel to apply the mask
418            writer.setRGB(i, r & reader.getRed(i), g & reader.getGreen(i), b & reader.getBlue(i));
419          });
420    };
421  }
422
423  /**
424   * Creates a pattern that plays this one, but at a different brightness. Brightness multipliers
425   * are applied per-channel in the RGB space; no HSL or HSV conversions are applied. Multipliers
426   * are also uncapped, which may result in the original colors washing out and appearing less
427   * saturated or even just a bright white.
428   *
429   * <p>This method is predominantly intended for dimming LEDs to avoid painfully bright or
430   * distracting patterns from playing (apologies to the 2024 NE Greater Boston field staff).
431   *
432   * <p>For example, dimming can be done simply by adding a call to `atBrightness` at the end of a
433   * pattern:
434   *
435   * <pre>
436   *   // Solid red, but at 50% brightness
437   *   LEDPattern.solid(Color.kRed).atBrightness(Percent.of(50));
438   *
439   *   // Solid white, but at only 10% (i.e. ~0.5V)
440   *   LEDPattern.solid(Color.kWhite).atBrightness(Percent.of(10));
441   * </pre>
442   *
443   * @param relativeBrightness the multiplier to apply to all channels to modify brightness
444   * @return the input pattern, displayed at
445   */
446  default LEDPattern atBrightness(Dimensionless relativeBrightness) {
447    double multiplier = relativeBrightness.in(Value);
448
449    return (reader, writer) -> {
450      applyTo(
451          reader,
452          (i, r, g, b) -> {
453            // Clamp RGB values to keep them in the range [0, 255].
454            // Otherwise, the casts to byte would result in values like 256 wrapping to 0
455
456            writer.setRGB(
457                i,
458                (int) MathUtil.clamp(r * multiplier, 0, 255),
459                (int) MathUtil.clamp(g * multiplier, 0, 255),
460                (int) MathUtil.clamp(b * multiplier, 0, 255));
461          });
462    };
463  }
464
465  /** A pattern that turns off all LEDs. */
466  LEDPattern kOff = solid(Color.kBlack);
467
468  /**
469   * Creates a pattern that displays a single static color along the entire length of the LED strip.
470   *
471   * @param color the color to display
472   * @return the pattern
473   */
474  static LEDPattern solid(Color color) {
475    return (reader, writer) -> {
476      int bufLen = reader.getLength();
477      for (int led = 0; led < bufLen; led++) {
478        writer.setLED(led, color);
479      }
480    };
481  }
482
483  /**
484   * Creates a pattern that works as a mask layer for {@link #mask(LEDPattern)} that illuminates
485   * only the portion of the LED strip corresponding with some progress. The mask pattern will start
486   * from the base and set LEDs to white at a proportion equal to the progress returned by the
487   * function. Some usages for this could be for displaying progress of a flywheel to its target
488   * velocity, progress of a complex autonomous sequence, or the height of an elevator.
489   *
490   * <p>For example, creating a mask for displaying a red-to-blue gradient, starting from the red
491   * end, based on where an elevator is in its range of travel.
492   *
493   * <pre>
494   *   LEDPattern basePattern = gradient(Color.kRed, Color.kBlue);
495   *   LEDPattern progressPattern =
496   *     basePattern.mask(progressMaskLayer(() -> elevator.getHeight() / elevator.maxHeight());
497   * </pre>
498   *
499   * @param progressSupplier the function to call to determine the progress. This should return
500   *     values in the range [0, 1]; any values outside that range will be clamped.
501   * @return the mask pattern
502   */
503  static LEDPattern progressMaskLayer(DoubleSupplier progressSupplier) {
504    return (reader, writer) -> {
505      double progress = MathUtil.clamp(progressSupplier.getAsDouble(), 0, 1);
506
507      int bufLen = reader.getLength();
508      int max = (int) (bufLen * progress);
509
510      for (int led = 0; led < max; led++) {
511        writer.setLED(led, Color.kWhite);
512      }
513
514      for (int led = max; led < bufLen; led++) {
515        writer.setLED(led, Color.kBlack);
516      }
517    };
518  }
519
520  /**
521   * Display a set of colors in steps across the length of the LED strip. No interpolation is done
522   * between colors. Colors are specified by the first LED on the strip to show that color. The last
523   * color in the map will be displayed all the way to the end of the strip. LEDs positioned before
524   * the first specified step will be turned off (you can think of this as if there's a 0 -> black
525   * step by default)
526   *
527   * <pre>
528   *   // Display red from 0-33%, white from 33% - 67%, and blue from 67% to 100%
529   *   steps(Map.of(0.00, Color.kRed, 0.33, Color.kWhite, 0.67, Color.kBlue))
530   *
531   *   // Half off, half on
532   *   steps(Map.of(0.5, Color.kWhite))
533   * </pre>
534   *
535   * @param steps a map of progress to the color to start displaying at that position along the LED
536   *     strip
537   * @return a motionless step pattern
538   */
539  static LEDPattern steps(Map<? extends Number, Color> steps) {
540    if (steps.isEmpty()) {
541      // no colors specified
542      DriverStation.reportWarning("Creating LED steps with no colors!", false);
543      return kOff;
544    }
545
546    if (steps.size() == 1 && steps.keySet().iterator().next().doubleValue() == 0) {
547      // only one color specified, just show a static color
548      DriverStation.reportWarning("Creating LED steps with only one color!", false);
549      return solid(steps.values().iterator().next());
550    }
551
552    return (reader, writer) -> {
553      int bufLen = reader.getLength();
554
555      // precompute relevant positions for this buffer so we don't need to do a check
556      // on every single LED index
557      var stopPositions = new LongToObjectHashMap<Color>();
558      steps.forEach(
559          (progress, color) -> {
560            stopPositions.put((int) Math.floor(progress.doubleValue() * bufLen), color);
561          });
562
563      Color currentColor = Color.kBlack;
564      for (int led = 0; led < bufLen; led++) {
565        currentColor = Objects.requireNonNullElse(stopPositions.get(led), currentColor);
566
567        writer.setLED(led, currentColor);
568      }
569    };
570  }
571
572  /** Types of gradients. */
573  enum GradientType {
574    /**
575     * A continuous gradient, where the gradient wraps around to allow for seamless scrolling
576     * effects.
577     */
578    kContinuous,
579
580    /**
581     * A discontinuous gradient, where the first pixel is set to the first color of the gradient and
582     * the final pixel is set to the last color of the gradient. There is no wrapping effect, so
583     * scrolling effects will display an obvious seam.
584     */
585    kDiscontinuous
586  }
587
588  /**
589   * Creates a pattern that displays a non-animated gradient of colors across the entire length of
590   * the LED strip. Colors are evenly distributed along the full length of the LED strip. The
591   * gradient type is configured with the {@code type} parameter, allowing the gradient to be either
592   * continuous (no seams, good for scrolling effects) or discontinuous (a clear seam is visible,
593   * but the gradient applies to the full length of the LED strip without needing to use some space
594   * for wrapping).
595   *
596   * @param type the type of gradient (continuous or discontinuous)
597   * @param colors the colors to display in the gradient
598   * @return a motionless gradient pattern
599   */
600  static LEDPattern gradient(GradientType type, Color... colors) {
601    if (colors.length == 0) {
602      // Nothing to display
603      DriverStation.reportWarning("Creating a gradient with no colors!", false);
604      return kOff;
605    }
606
607    if (colors.length == 1) {
608      // No gradients with one color
609      DriverStation.reportWarning("Creating a gradient with only one color!", false);
610      return solid(colors[0]);
611    }
612
613    final int numSegments = colors.length;
614
615    return (reader, writer) -> {
616      int bufLen = reader.getLength();
617      int ledsPerSegment =
618          switch (type) {
619            case kContinuous -> bufLen / numSegments;
620            case kDiscontinuous -> (bufLen - 1) / (numSegments - 1);
621          };
622
623      for (int led = 0; led < bufLen; led++) {
624        int colorIndex = (led / ledsPerSegment) % numSegments;
625        int nextColorIndex = (colorIndex + 1) % numSegments;
626        double t = (led / (double) ledsPerSegment) % 1;
627
628        Color color = colors[colorIndex];
629        Color nextColor = colors[nextColorIndex];
630        int gradientColor =
631            Color.lerpRGB(
632                color.red,
633                color.green,
634                color.blue,
635                nextColor.red,
636                nextColor.green,
637                nextColor.blue,
638                t);
639
640        writer.setRGB(
641            led,
642            Color.unpackRGB(gradientColor, Color.RGBChannel.kRed),
643            Color.unpackRGB(gradientColor, Color.RGBChannel.kGreen),
644            Color.unpackRGB(gradientColor, Color.RGBChannel.kBlue));
645      }
646    };
647  }
648
649  /**
650   * Creates an LED pattern that displays a rainbow across the color wheel. The rainbow pattern will
651   * stretch across the entire length of the LED strip.
652   *
653   * @param saturation the saturation of the HSV colors, in [0, 255]
654   * @param value the value of the HSV colors, in [0, 255]
655   * @return the rainbow pattern
656   */
657  static LEDPattern rainbow(int saturation, int value) {
658    return (reader, writer) -> {
659      int bufLen = reader.getLength();
660      for (int i = 0; i < bufLen; i++) {
661        int hue = ((i * 180) / bufLen) % 180;
662        writer.setHSV(i, hue, saturation, value);
663      }
664    };
665  }
666}
